content: I think sticking to sports is boring, but the politicization of nearly everything can grow tiresome after a while. When looking around to see what Steve Kerr thought about the Warrior’s performance, that is relegated behind his thoughts on whatever asinine thing Trump did or said. I, personally, want to know both things. The problem becomes when the political is elevated over the sports part every single time. I assume there’s click based evidence to support this editorial push. It’s just not always for me. The Ringer is a particularly interesting circumstance. As a new website, it’s growing into and out of coverage areas and one place I’d like to see less of is it’s political coverage. It’s one thing when a seasoned vet like Mr. Curtis delves into the Republican National Convention. It’s another thing when “24-year-old Pop culture writer X” who I’m just getting to know posts a story on the issue of the day. That’s not what I’m here for. I can go to Slate or Salon or any of 100 other websites that allow people to write whatever the hell they want. But I suppose what I want or don’t want doesn’t matter. The obvious solution here is “Don’t read what you don’t want to” which is what I do. I just am particularly curious about who comes to the Ringer for political takes.
